, on the peninsula jutting out into the Aegean Sea.

Formerly named Agrilia and inhabited by local Greeks until 1920s, Alaçatı was long forgotten until 1990s when it started to attract Turkish intellectuals yearning for a peaceful, rural haven. Since 2000s, it is much trendier and has a wider visitor profile, which includes many windsurfers.

The village lies 8 km east of Çeşme.

value: content=Perhaps the main attraction of the village, all of the village's old parts consist of very well preserved local Greek architecture of stone buildings lining cobbled streets.
content=Ancient windmills dating back to 19th century on the top of the hill overlooking the village. Windmills themselves are shadowed by much taller modern electricity-generating wind turbines.
content=The cove of Alaçatı lies on the leeward side of this much windy peninsula in Turkey's western tip, which means lots of wind but no visible waves towards the coast—perfect for
! There are some schools offering windsurfing training on the beach.
content=A great private beach in Alaçatı, mostly preferred by holidaymakers from Istanbul.

There is a lively street market held every Saturday, with fresh fruit and vegetables, clothes, and various other products on the offer.

content=A hotel housed in a historical building, offering rooms with air-con, en-suite bathrooms, wireless internet access.

content=A small hotel in a historic building with traditional architecture in downtown Alaçatı, in a big garden. Provides organic breakfast (from garden), and free shuttles to beaches around Alaçatı, as well as boat tours to fishing and swimming spots.
content=Hotel of 22 rooms build in 2011 have pool, fitness ,jacuzzi and spa.
